title: 110_s1982
content: The Act is titled the "United States Employee Ownership Bank Act" and includes findings. The United States has lost over 3 million manufacturing jobs in the past 6 years, with a record-breaking trade deficit at the end of 2006. Congress must prioritize preserving and increasing decent paying jobs, including providing assistance for employees to buy their own companies. It is proposed to establish the United States Employee Ownership Bank to boost employment, similar to the creation of the United States Export-Import Bank during the Great Depression. The United States Employee Ownership Bank is being established within the Department of the Treasury to preserve and expand jobs in the United States. The United States Employee Ownership Bank is established within the Department of the Treasury to preserve and expand jobs in the United States. The United States Employee Ownership Bank (referred to as the "Bank") is established by the Secretary of the Treasury to promote employee ownership and participation in company decision-making. The Bank provides loans and loan guarantees to employees for purchasing businesses through employee stock ownership plans or worker-owned cooperatives, and grants to States and organizations experienced in developing employee-owned businesses. The United States Employee Ownership Bank promotes employee ownership and participation in company decision-making by providing education, outreach, technical assistance, and training to help employees become business owners and create sustainable businesses through employee stock ownership plans or worker cooperatives. The United States Employee Ownership Bank supports employee ownership and participation in company decision-making by requiring a business plan for subordinated loans or loan guarantees. The plan must show that at least 51% of the company is owned by an employee stock ownership plan or worker-owned cooperative, with employees involved in the board of directors and day-to-day operations. The United States Employee Ownership Bank requires a feasibility study from a third party to determine if an employee stock ownership plan or worker-owned cooperative can generate enough profit to repay any loans. The Bank also insures subordinated loans and loan guarantees against non-repayment, with annual premiums set to cover costs. The United States Employee Ownership Bank collects premiums and fees to cover losses from insurance and loan guarantees. Loans and guarantees bear interest at rates determined by the Secretary. The United States Employee Ownership Bank determines interest rates for loans and guarantees based on the cost of borrowing or 4 percent, with a term not exceeding 12 years. The Secretary may require the Bank to target key groups and provide technical assistance for activities. The United States Employee Ownership Bank offers loans and guarantees with interest rates based on borrowing costs or 4 percent for up to 12 years. The Secretary may require the Bank to target specific groups and provide technical assistance. The Bank also conducts training workshops, distributes materials on employee ownership, and supports the development of employee-owned networks to promote successful participation techniques. The Secretary will promulgate regulations within 90 days to ensure the safety of the Bank and prevent competition with commercial financial institutions. The Bank will be headed by a Director appointed by the Secretary, who can hire necessary staff. Authorization of appropriations is granted. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Secretary of the Treasury for $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, with additional funds as needed for this Act.
